summary: This document is a legal opinion prepared by French attorney William Julie for Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team, analyzing French extradition law. It concludes that France can extradite its nationals to the US under the existing treaty, and that Maxwell's planned waiver and flight risk make her extradition likely if she flees to France. The opinion was used in her US bail proceedings to counter the government's claim that France would not extradite her.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in US criminal proceedings, charged with offenses related to sexual activities with Jeffrey Epstein and minor girls. She is a dual US/French citizen seeking bail, and the opinion analyzes the likelihood of her extradition from France if she flees.

persons.name: William Julie
persons.role: Attorney at law, author of legal opinion
persons.context: French attorney who authored this legal opinion on French extradition law at the request of Olivier Laude, acting for Ghislaine Maxwell's US counsel.

persons.name: Olivier Laude
persons.role: Partner at French law firm Laude Esquier Champey
persons.context: French attorney who instructed William Julie to draft the extradition opinion on behalf of Cohen & Gresser LLP, counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP, US counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, mentioned as having reviewed charges with her.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP, US counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, mentioned as having reviewed charges with her.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the other party in the sexual activities with minor girls that Ghislaine Maxwell is alleged to have facilitated.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Judge before whom Ghislaine Maxwell swore her affidavit and waiver of extradition.

Olivier Laude, acting on behalf of Maxwell's US counsel, instructed William Julie to draft the legal opinion.
Mark S. Cohen is listed as US counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell and reviewed the charges with her.
Christian R. Everdell is listed as US counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell and reviewed the charges with her.
Maxwell is alleged to have played a role in sexual activities between Jeffrey Epstein and minor girls.

events.title: Bail Hearing for Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: US Government argued against bail, stating France would not extradite a French citizen. The court subsequently denied bail, citing Maxwell's international ties and French citizenship.

events.title: Filing of Superseding Indictment
events.description: Superseding Indictment S1 20 Cr. 330 (MN) was filed against Ghislaine Maxwell, containing grand jury charges.

events.title: Execution of Extradition Waiver
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell executed an affidavit and irrevocable waiver of her right to contest extradition from France to the US, as referenced in the opinion and included as Exhibit B.

events.title: Signing of US-France Extradition Treaty
events.description: The Extradition Treaty between the United States and France was signed in Paris, governing extradition requests between the two countries.

locations: Metropolitan Detention Center, Brooklyn, New York
keyFacts: The legal opinion concludes that France can legally extradite its own nationals to the United States under the 1996 Extradition Treaty, which contains no prohibition, contrary to the US government's claim at Maxwell's bail hearing.

Ghislaine Maxwell planned to execute an 'irrevocable waiver' of her right to contest extradition from France to the US, a key strategic move to support her bail application by mitigating flight risk concerns.

The opinion argues that if Maxwell fled to France after violating bail, French courts would likely keep her in custody and the French government would be highly likely to issue an extradition decree, citing diplomatic relations and the lack of legal bars.
The document includes Maxwell's signed affidavit and waiver of extraition (Exhibit B), sworn before Judge Alison J. Nathan, consenting to extradition under the relevant treaties.

The analysis finds that the crimes Maxwell is charged with in the US (conspiracy to entice minors, etc.) would qualify as the crime of 'proxénétisme' under French law, satisfying the dual criminality requirement for extradition.
